repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

comment_data.body:
Based on a very quick look:

1. You could reasonably extend this to cimported modules (if it was easy).
2. Cython has a bit of infrastructure to track `as_cython_attribute` to work out what things come from the `cython` module. I'm not sure whether it'll be available here though because annotations are ignored fairly early.

But this seems like a good initial level for what we treat was needing an elevated warning.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -14258,6 +14258,14 @@ def analyse_type_annotation(self, env, assigned_value=None):
         with env.new_c_type_context(in_c_type_context=explicit_ctype):
             arg_type = annotation.analyse_as_type(env)
 
+            if isinstance(annotation, NameNode):
+                if not env.lookup(annotation.name):
+                    warning(annotation.pos, "Unknown type declaration in annotation, ignoring", level=1)
+            if isinstance(annotation, AttributeNode):
+                module_scope = annotation.obj.analyse_as_module(env)
+                if module_scope and module_scope.name == 'cython' and not module_scope.lookup_type(annotation.attribute):

comment_data.body:
Here, I wanted also to test the following case:
```python
foo7: cython.bar = 1
```
But it yields following warnings:
```
14:16: Unknown type declaration 'cython.bar' in annotation, ignoring
25:10: 'cpdef_method' redeclared
36:10: 'cpdef_cname_method' redeclared
977:29: Ambiguous exception value, same as default return value: 0
1018:46: Ambiguous exception value, same as default return value: 0
1108:29: Ambiguous exception value, same as default return value: 0
```

Not sure why there are additional warnings. It is the reason why it is not included in the test...

+    foo2: Bar = 1  # warning

+    foo4: cython.int = 1
+    foo5: stdint.bar = 5  # warning
+    foo6: object = 1

comment_data.body: I'm not sure this is necessarily referring to a module. And even if it was, looking up the attribute name in the current scope won't find the name in that module. There's `typing` module support now, so we might want to special case that. And the `.entry` of the attribute's object might also give hints.

comment_data.body:
Yes, in pure python mode, any annotation that is not recognized in cython is silently ignored and python object is used by default. E.g.:
```python
@cython.cfunc
def bar(a: cython.bar) -> cython.void:
    print(a)
```
Is compiled silently on master branch to:
```c
static void __pyx_f_4test_bar(PyObject *__pyx_v_a) {
```
 The scope of this PR is to  print warning for the cases where we are sure that the annotation is broken. So in this case the PR produces the same C code but raises a warning:

```
 cython -3a test.py
warning: test.py:4:17: Unknown type declaration 'cython.bar' in annotation, ignoring
```
@scoder do you think this check should go elsewhere where this case is handled (and ignored)? My personal opinion is that this warnings should be handled in one single place.

comment_data.body:
I am pretty new to Cython code-base so maybe here I need a help. This test:

```python
if not env.lookup(annotation.obj.name):
    # `module` is undeclared
    warning(annotation.pos, ...)
```

is checking whether for the annotation expression `A.B`  if the `A` name is known/defined. If not, it is raising the warning. Is this incorrect? It is pretty the same as previous test:
```
if not env.lookup(annotation.name):
    warning(annotation.pos, "Unknown type declaration '%s' in annotation, ignoring" % annotation.name, level=1)
```

comment_data.body:
Not sure if this is quite the point that scoder was making, but

```
annotation.obj.name
```

could fail. `annotation.obj` isn't necessarily a name node. Some (non-exhaustive) examples:

```
mod.a.b  # I think obj will be mod.a
func().b  # obj will be func()  - I can't imagine many times this'll be a useful annotation for Cython, but it shouldn't crash!
(1 + x).b  # again, unlikely
```

There's no need to produce a sensible message for all of these, but they shouldn't crash

comment_data.body:
So I think what's happening here is that missing an attribute lookup on `cython` causes it to cause `CythonScope.load_cythonscope` which loads "TestClass" and some memoryview code. I think this is harmless (because it does get dropped) but does cause the warnings. Running it outside the test suite gives:

```
warning: TestClass:25:10: 'cpdef_method' redeclared 
warning: TestClass:36:10: 'cpdef_cname_method' redeclared 
warning: View.MemoryView:977:29: Ambiguous exception value, same as default return value: 0
warning: View.MemoryView:1018:46: Ambiguous exception value, same as default return value: 0
warning: View.MemoryView:1108:29: Ambiguous exception value, same as default return value: 0
```

What we've done before: in the `_WARNINGS` string you can have comments and the warnings don't need to be in order. So just add these warnings with a comment at the end of the list of warnings:

```
# Spurious warnings from utility code - not part of the core test
25:10: 'cpdef_method' redeclared
36:10: 'cpdef_cname_method' redeclared  
977:29: Ambiguous exception value, same as default return value: 0
1018:46: Ambiguous exception value, same as default return value: 0
1108:29: Ambiguous exception value, same as default return value: 0
"""
```

comment_data.body: The other thing that might help - the `AnnotationNode` stores a string representation of the annotation already so you don't necessarily need to construct the string yourself. Not sure whether that lets you simplify too much might it might be useful

comment_data.body:
Fixed to : 
```
Found C type 'Py_ssize_t' in a Python annotation. Did you mean to use a 'cython.Py_ssize_t'?
```
But @da-woods does this warning have any meaning except unitests? `warning()` call is missing `level=` hence it is raised **only during unittests**:

```
(cython39) matus@MacBook-Pro:~/dev/cython/test$ cat test.py
import cython

def main():
    a: Py_ssize_t = 6
(cython39) matus@MacBook-Pro:~/dev/cython/test$ cython -3 test.py
warning: test.py:4:7: Unknown type declaration 'Py_ssize_t' in annotation, ignoring
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -15,7 +15,7 @@ cdef class C:
 _WARNINGS = """
 9:7: Found Python 2.x type 'long' in a Python annotation. Did you mean to use 'cython.long'?
 10:7: Found C type 'Py_ssize_t' in a Python annotation. Did you mean to use a Python type?

comment_data.body:
Sorry for the slow reply...

Without the `level` call warnings aren't shown by default. But they aren't just for the CI. You can turn them on with compiler options. I think `show_all_warnings` as [a Cythonize argument](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/source_files_and_compilation.html#cythonize-arguments) will do it.

So it isn't *just* for the unittests, but most people probably don't see them. As I said, it'd be welcome, but not necessary for this PR.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

 10:7: Found C type 'Py_ssize_t' in a Python annotation. Did you mean to use a Python type?

comment_data.body:
> So it isn't _just_ for the unittests, but most people probably don't see them. As I said, it'd be welcome, but not necessary for this PR.

OK fair enough. I learn new think every day. The message is changed in PR so I am closing this conversation.
